header.title: Table of Questions for the Meaning of the Words (Part Six)

central_thesis: This text outlines a complex Lurianic Kabbalistic cosmology, detailing the origins and functions of divine emanations (Otiot, Sefirot, Partzufim) through various stages of contraction (Tzimtzum Aleph, Tzimtzum Bet) and the interplay of divine light (Ohr) and vessels (Kelim). It emphasizes the structural and functional differences between these stages, particularly regarding the role of Aleph and Yod as fundamental 'Shorashim' (roots) and the formation of distinct realms and spiritual constructs like the Parsa and Rakia.

structure_content.chapter_title: What is Aleph in the Vav de SAG?
structure_content.summary: Explores the dual nature of Yod and Aleph as Shorashim, with Yod as the primary point from Tzimtzum Aleph and Aleph as the second Shoresh representing Tzimtzum Bet, linking Bina and Malchut to form the structural basis for dividing upper/lower degrees, leading all twenty-two Otiot.

Otiot are Kelim (vessels) for the reception of Shefa (divine abundance/light), formed from Reshimot (impressions) remaining after Ohr Histalkut (withdrawal of light). They are considered twenty-two heads of discernments from which all Partzufim are built.

structure_content.chapter_title: What are AHP in their Place?
structure_content.summary: Defined as the first three Tikkunim (rectifications) of the thirteen Tikkunim of Dikna (beard), which did not emerge from the Behinot Rosh (aspects of the head) but are Behinot GE (Garon-Chazeh-Tifaret) de Rosh of the Dikna, named AHP only with respect to Rosh de SAG.

Means 'illumination and hardness or darkness,' implying the lower Hey (Behina Dalet), specifically the Nekuda (point) concealed inside the Vav, which is the Melafom that poured Yesod de AK to HB de Nekudim, remaining concealed in Yesod de Ima.

structure_content.chapter_title: What is the Fissuring of the Parsa?
structure_content.summary: Implies the annulment of the Gevul (boundary) within the Parsa, allowing Bina and ZON (Zeir Anpin and Nukva) inside the Toch (interior) of the degree to return and re-integrate as in the beginning.

structure_content.chapter_title: What is One Over the Other?
structure_content.summary: Describes a state where Sefirot (emanations) stand separated due to disparity of form, unable to receive or bestow upon each other, arranged hierarchically with the Panim (face) of the Tachton (lower) aligning with the Achor (back) of the Elyon (upper).

One of three Behinot of Nekudot (vowel points) that indicate He'arat Zivug (illumination from conjunction), specifically when the lower Hey is in Keter de Nekudim in the Eynaim and YHV in the AHP, positioned above the Otiot YHV.
Refers to the first Sefira in every degree, which contains all Behinot below it and is considered the kernel, making all other Behinot secondary and unworthy of a unique name.

Describes the intensity of Ohr (light) emergence, correlating greater Aviut (coarseness) in the Masach (screen) with stronger Ohr output and downward expansion, particularly when the lower Hey connects with the Nikvey Eynaim.
The Otiot are the Kelim (vessels) where the Atzmut (essence) clothes, containing twenty-two heads of discernments, from which all the Partzufim are built.
Keter of the Nekudim, positioned above the Rakia (firmament), is considered Mayim Elyonim (upper waters) and represents the Zachar (male) principle.
HB (Hochma-Bina) de Nekudim is the Mayim Tachtonim (lower waters) under the Rakia, representing the Nekeva (female) principle, specifically Bina, ZA, and Malchut below the Rakia.
Refers to Answer No. 7 regarding Holam, indicating Melafom is a type of Nekuda located 'inside the Vav' of the Otiot de YHV, also called Shuruk.
Se'arot Dikna (hairs of the beard) are called Mazla, symbolizing the gradual, bit-by-bit flow of Shefa (abundance) from the divine until it joins the greater Orot (lights) in the Olamot (worlds).

Refers to the two Behinot Reshimot (impressions) – the first Hey in SAG and the lower Hey in AK ha Pnimi – joining in the Masach, forming the two female principles, Bina and Malchut, which are then incorporated into every Zivug (conjunction) with the Ohr Elyon.

Refers to the cessation of the Light of life below the Sium (end) of the Kav (line), the point of Tzimtzum (contraction), causing the Kelim (vessels) that fell to BYA (Beria, Yetzira, Assiya) to be considered 'dead' due to their separation from the Light of life.
Refers to Answer No. 7, identifying Holam as the Upper Nekudot.

structure_content.chapter_title: What are Nekudot Under the Otiot?
structure_content.summary: Refers to Answer No. 7, specifically identifying Hevel de Tzipornaim of the Raglaim (nails of the feet) as the Nekudot under the Otiot, distinguishing them from Holam (above) and Melafom (inside).
Refers to Answer No. 4, indicating it is related to Butzina de Kardinuta, meaning a 'spark of hardness/darkness.'
Behina Aleph (first aspect) in the Rosh (head), specifically Hochma de Rosh (Wisdom of the Head), where the ascent of the lower Hey created Behina Nukva (female aspect) in Hochma.

Refers to Answer No. 20, further explaining them as Nekavim (foramens) formed when the two Heys (representing Midat ha Rachamim with Din) joined and the lower Hey rose to the Eynaim, creating Behina Nukva in all Sefirot up to Hochma.

structure_content.chapter_title: What is the Opening of the Eynaim?
structure_content.summary: Refers to the He'arat Hochma (illumination of Wisdom), which is called the 'Opening of the Eynaim' because Eynaim (eyes) signify Hochma.
A diaphragm-like partition, analogous to a liver, separating the upper (GAR de MA and BON) from the lower (Eser Sefirot de Nekudim) Partzufim, effectively dividing a single Partzuf into two.

A contraction on Behina Bet (second aspect), similar to Tzimtzum Aleph on Behina Dalet, where the Kav Ohr Ein Sof (line of Infinite Light) stopped at Bina de NHY de AK, leading to Bina, ZA, and Malchut remaining without Ohr and forming the three separated Olamot (worlds) of BYA.

structure_content.chapter_title: What are Tzipornaim of the Raglaim?
structure_content.summary: The Behinot Sium (ending aspects) of every Partzuf, specifically Malchut de NHY (Malchut of Netzach, Hod, Yesod) of the Partzuf, called Etzbaot Raglaim (fingernails of the feet). This additional force, related to Bina in the Tzimtzum, is at the Sium NHY; when at Tabur, it is Parsa.

The Parsa (partition) placed within the Eser Sefirot of each degree by the connection of the two points, Bina and Malchut, which distinguishes Keter and Hochma (Male Mayim Elyonim) from Bina, ZA, and Malchut (Female Mayim Tachtonim).
Refers to Answer No. 7, indicating that the Melafom is also called Shuruk, explained as a Nekuda inside the Otiot de YHV/HB.

The Partzuf Se'arot (hairs), emerging from Nikvey Eynaim up, formed by the first Zivug for Partzuf Nekudim in Nikvey Eynaim of Rosh de SAG, where AHP of Rosh de SAG did not emerge outwardly, with Se'arot Dikna emerging below.
Refers to Answer No. 28, indicating they are part of the Partzuf Se'arot emerging from Nikvey Eynaim down in Behinot AHP (Awzen, Hotem, Peh).
Behinot AHP (Awzen, Hotem, Peh) that emerged from the first Rosh de Dikna, specifically the first three Tikkunim de Dikna (Behinot GE), accumulating Shefa (abundance) into Behinat Guf (body aspect).

key_concepts.definition: The second Shoresh (root) of the Olamot (worlds), made in Tzimtzum Bet (Second Contraction) on the two points Bina and Malchut, forming the line of the Aleph and structurally dividing upper and lower degrees. It is considered the true Shoresh to the Olamot and is at the head of the twenty-two Otiot.

The first Shoresh, made in the first Tzimtzum (Tzimtzum Aleph) only on the point of Malchut (Behina Dalet). It is considered the genuine Shoresh of the Otiot, a primordial Shoresh serving the Otiot in hiding.

The Kelim (vessels) that receive the Shefa (abundance/light). They are formed from the Reshimot (impressions) that remain after the Histalkut Ohr (withdrawal of light). They are described as twenty-two heads of discernments from which all the Partzufim are built.
A contraction that occurred only on a single Nekuda (point), Behina Dalet (Malchut). It is considered the Shoresh de Shoresh (root of the root) but not the real Shoresh of the Olamot.

A contraction that occurred on two Nekudot, Bina and Malchut, creating a Kav (line) and Rakia/Parsa. It is considered the real Shoresh of the Olamot, leading to the division of the Eser Sefirot (Ten Emanations) into upper and lower Behinot and the formation of BYA (Beria, Yetzira, Assiya).
Formed from the Reshimot (impressions) that remain after the Histalkut Ohr (withdrawal of light). The Otiot are fundamentally Kelim for the reception of Shefa.

Complex arrangements of Sefirot that act as independent entities, through which the divine light manifests. The text describes HaVaYaH (the Tetragrammaton) as being divided into four Partzufim: Hochma, Bina, ZA (Zeir Anpin), and Malchut.

A separating membrane or diaphragm-like boundary, created by the connection of two Nekudot (Bina and Malchut) in Tzimtzum Bet. It divides the Elyonim (upper Partzufim like GAR de MA and BON) from the Tachtonim (lower Partzufim like Eser Sefirot de Nekudim).

Another name for Parsa, created by the connection of two Nekudot (Bina and Malchut) in Tzimtzum Bet. It distinguishes Keter and Hochma (as Male Mayim Elyonim) from Bina, ZA, and Malchut (as Female Mayim Tachtonim).

Indicate the He'arat Zivug (illumination from conjunction). They manifest as Holam (above Otiot), Melafom/Shuruk (inside Otiot), and Tzipornaim of the Raglaim (under Otiot), reflecting different stages of the lower Hey's position and the flow of Ohr.

A Nekuda (vowel point) where the lower Hey is positioned in Keter de Nekudim (Crown of the Points) in the Eynaim (eyes) and YHV in the AHP, appearing above the Otiot YHV. It signifies that Ohr Keter (Light of Crown) is not fully poured to HB (Hochma-Bina).

A Nekuda found inside the Vav (Otiot de YHV/HB), where the Nekuda de lower Hey is. It is specifically the He'arat Yesod de AK (illumination of Foundation of Primordial Man) on Behina Melafom. Also called Shuruk.
Another name for Melafom, defined as a Nekuda located inside the Otiot.
Keter (Crown) of the Nekudim (Points), which is considered the Zachar (male) principle and is located above the Rakia.

HB (Hochma-Bina) of the Nekudim (Points), which is considered the Nekeva (female) principle and is located under the Rakia. More specifically, Female Mayim Tachtonim refer to Bina, ZA, and Malchut below the Rakia.

key_concepts.term: AHP (Awzen, Hotem, Peh / Ear, Nose, Mouth)
key_concepts.definition: In their place, refers to the first three Tikkunim (rectifications) of the Dikna (beard) that did not emerge outwardly from the Rosh Behinot (aspects of the head) but are specifically the GE (Garon-Chazeh-Tifaret) de Rosh of the Dikna, named AHP relative to Rosh de SAG.
Signifies 'illumination and hardness or darkness,' representing the lower Hey (Behina Dalet), particularly as the concealed Nekuda (point) within Yesod de Ima (Foundation of Mother).

The annulment of the Gevul (boundary) within the Parsa, allowing Bina and ZON (Zeir Anpin and Nukva) to return to the Toch (interior) of the degree, thereby re-integrating the lower Sefirot with the upper ones.

A state where Sefirot (emanations) are separated due to a disparity of form, preventing mutual reception or bestowal. They stand hierarchically with the Panim (face) of the Tachton (lower) aligning with the Achor (back) of the Elyon (upper).
Describes secondary Behinot (aspects) in a degree that do not merit a distinct name, compared to the primary 'kernel' Sefira which contains all Behinot below it.

Refers to the intensity of Ohr (light) emergence, directly correlating with the Aviut (coarseness) in the Masach (screen). Greater Aviut leads to stronger Ohr output and downward expansion, especially when the lower Hey connects with the Nikvey Eynaim.

A term used for Se'arot Dikna (hairs of the beard), symbolizing the gradual, bit-by-bit flow of Shefa (abundance) from the divine until it converges with the greater Orot (lights) in the Olamot (worlds).

Refers to the two female Reshimot (impressions) – the first Hey in SAG and the lower Hey in AK ha Pnimi – which join in the Masach (screen), forming Bina and Malchut. These are subsequently incorporated into every Zivug (conjunction) with the Ohr Elyon (Upper Light).

The cessation of the Light of life below the Sium (end) of the Kav (line), which is the new point of Tzimtzum (contraction). Kelim (vessels) that fell to BYA (Beria, Yetzira, Assiya) are considered 'dead' due to their departure from the Light of life.
Identified as Holam, a type of Nekuda (vowel point) situated above the Otiot.
Identified as Hevel de Tzipornaim of the Raglaim (nails of the feet), representing a type of Nekuda located beneath the Otiot.
A 'spark of hardness/darkness,' referring to Butzina de Kardinuta (Candle of Darkness/Hardness).
Behina Aleph (first aspect) in the Rosh (head), specifically Hochma de Rosh (Wisdom of the Head). The ascent of the lower Hey there creates Behina Nukva (female aspect) in Hochma.

Nekavim (foramens) formed when the two Heys (representing Midat ha Rachamim with Din) joined and the lower Hey rose to the Eynaim (eyes), creating Behina Nukva (female aspect) in all Sefirot up to Hochma, prior to which Nukva was only in Peh (mouth).
Refers to the He'arat Hochma (illumination of Wisdom), named so because Eynaim (eyes) signify Hochma.

key_concepts.term: Tzipornaim of the Raglaim (Fingernails of the Feet)
key_concepts.definition: The Behinot Sium (ending aspects) of every Partzuf, specifically Malchut de NHY (Malchut of Netzach, Hod, Yesod) of the Partzuf. This additional force, related to Bina in the Tzimtzum, is present at the Sium NHY; when this force is at the Tabur, it is called Parsa.

The Partzuf Se'arot (hairs) emerging from Nikvey Eynaim (eye openings) upwards. This occurred during the first Zivug (conjunction) for Partzuf Nekudim in Nikvey Eynaim of Rosh de SAG, representing a division of the degree affecting the Partzuf.
Partzuf Se'arot (hairs) emerging from Nikvey Eynaim downwards in Behinot AHP (Awzen, Hotem, Peh). Also called Mazla.

key_concepts.term: Shibolet ha Zakan (Ear of Grain of the Beard)
key_concepts.definition: Refers to Behinot AHP (Awzen, Hotem, Peh) that emerged from the first Rosh de Dikna, specifically the first three Tikkunim de Dikna (Behinot GE), where the Shefa (abundance) accumulates into Behinat Guf (body aspect).

practical_system.description: The text primarily describes a theoretical, cosmological system rather than a direct magical 'system' with explicit rituals. However, for the advanced Qabalist, understanding this complex Lurianic framework *is* the practical system. It provides the detailed map for visualizing and interacting with the energetic structures of the cosmos and the human soul (which mirrors the macrocosm). The 'magic' here is the profound comprehension and internal assimilation of these divine mechanics, enabling the practitioner to consciously engage in Tikkun (rectification). The text details the 'how' of creation and rectification through the interplay of Ohr (light), Kelim (vessels), Tzimtzum (contraction), Reshimot (impressions), and the formation of Partzufim (divine personas). This understanding informs all advanced Qabalistic practices, allowing the magician to trace spiritual lineages, identify points of rectification, and direct intention within the framework of the divine emanations.
tools: Intellectual understanding and study of Kabbalistic texts.
Meditative visualization of energetic structures (Partzufim, Sefirot, Nekudot).
The Hebrew language, particularly the Otiot (letters) and their combinations (e.g., HaVaYaH fulfillments).
rituals: Lurianic-based meditations focusing on visualizing Partzufim and Sefirot and their interactions.
Pathworking to navigate and understand the cosmic structures described.
Kavvanot (intentional prayers/contemplations) aligned with specific divine processes and emanations.
Practices aimed at Tikkun, or self-transformation through aligning with cosmic rectification processes.

relevant_quotes.text: Thus, you can see how there are two Shorashim to the Olamot: the Yod is the first Shoresh, made in the first Tzimtzum only on the point of Malchut, and the Aleph is the second Shoresh, made in Tzimtzum Bet on the two points Bina and Malchut together.

It is known that connecting two Nekudot together creates a Kav, longitudinally or across. Hence, Tzimtzum Bet is called a Kav, because of the two Nekudot that joined in this Tzimtzum, as it says, “and they two went." Because of that it is called Rakia, or Parsa, which is like a Kav laid across, separating the Elyonim from the Tachtonim.

Only the Ot Aleph is considered the Shoresh of all the Otiot, since it is regarded as Tzimtzum Bet, being the true Shoresh to the Olamot. Hence, the Aleph is at the head of the twenty-two Otiot, and the Yod is considered a primordial Shoresh, serving the Otiot in hiding.

The greater the Aviut in the Masach, the more strongly the Ohr comes out. If the Aviut is frail, the Ohr does not come out strongly, meaning there is little Ohr Hozer, and the Komat Ohr it extends does not expand downward.
Parsa is the premises of the liver (diaphragm) separating the breathing organs, which are the sustenance, from the feeding organs. It seemingly creates two Gufim within a single Guf.
Life is until the place where Kav Ohr Ein Sof reaches. After the Sium of the Kav, meaning below the point of Tzimtzum, the Light of life ceases. This is Behinat Death.
Se'arot Dikna are called Mazla, as it is written, “Water shall flow from his branches etc." This is because their Shefa flows bit-by-bit until they join the greater Orot in the Olamot...

critical_analysis.relevance: This text is a foundational exposition of Lurianic Kabbalah, specifically detailing the intricate cosmology of the breaking of the vessels (Shevirat haKelim) and the subsequent Tikkun (rectification). Its relevance lies in providing precise definitions of key terms within this highly complex system, which are crucial for understanding the dynamic processes of creation, contraction, and the interaction of divine lights and vessels. It elucidates the mechanics of Partzufim formation and their internal structures, offering a technical lexicon for advanced Kabbalistic study and practice. It is essential for practitioners engaged in pathworking, meditation, and ritual based on Lurianic principles, as it clarifies the energetic flows and structural relationships within the spiritual realms.
critical_analysis.target_audience: Advanced students and practitioners of Lurianic Kabbalah, Qabalistic magic, and Western Esotericism who have a solid grounding in basic Qabalistic concepts (Sefirot, Tree of Life) and are moving into the more complex, dynamic, and often counter-intuitive Lurianic model of creation and rectification. It assumes prior knowledge of core concepts and focuses on their specific definitions and interrelations within this particular system.
